API Reference

This section provides detailed information about the myshift command-line interface and its modules.

Command Modules

The following modules provide the core functionality of myshift:

Next Shift

Next shift management for PagerDuty on-call schedules.

This module provides functionality to view the next upcoming on-call shift for a user, including: - Finding the next scheduled shift within a 3-month window - Filtering shifts by user (via ID or email) - Displaying shift details in a user-friendly format

myshift.next.next_main(args=None, config=None)[source]

Main entry point for the next command.

This function handles the next sub-command, allowing users to: 1. View the next upcoming shift for a specific user 2. Look ahead up to 3 months for the next shift 3. Identify users by ID or email

Command-line arguments:

schedule_id: Optional PagerDuty schedule ID to check –user-id: Optional user ID to check (overrides my_user from config) –user-email: Optional user email to check (overrides my_user from config)

Parameters:

  • args (Optional[List[str]]) – Optional command line arguments

  • config (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Optional configuration dictionary

Raises:

SystemExit – If required arguments are missing or if API calls fail

Return type:

None

Upcoming Shifts

Upcoming shifts management for PagerDuty on-call schedules.

This module provides functionality to view upcoming on-call shifts for a user, including: - Listing all upcoming shifts within a specified time window - Filtering shifts by user (via ID or email) - Configurable look-ahead period

myshift.upcoming.upcoming_main(args=None, config=None)[source]

Main entry point for the upcoming command.

This function handles the upcoming sub-command, allowing users to: 1. View all upcoming shifts for a specific user 2. Specify the look-ahead period 3. Identify users by ID or email

Command-line arguments:

schedule_id: Optional PagerDuty schedule ID to check –user-id: Optional user ID to check (overrides my_user from config) –user-email: Optional user email to check (overrides my_user from config) –weeks: Optional number of weeks to look ahead (default: 4)

Parameters:

  • args (Optional[List[str]]) – Optional command line arguments

  • config (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Optional configuration dictionary

Raises:

SystemExit – If required arguments are missing or if API calls fail

Return type:

None

Schedule Planning

Schedule planning for PagerDuty on-call schedules.

This module provides functionality to view and plan on-call schedules, including: - Viewing all shifts in a schedule for a specified time period - Displaying shifts with user information - Configurable look-ahead period

myshift.plan.plan_main(args=None, config=None)[source]

Main entry point for the plan command.

This function handles the plan sub-command, allowing users to: 1. View all shifts in a schedule for a specified time period 2. See which users are on call during each shift 3. Configure the look-ahead period

Command-line arguments:

schedule_id: Optional PagerDuty schedule ID to check –weeks: Optional number of weeks to look ahead (default: 4)

Parameters:

  • args (Optional[List[str]]) – Optional command line arguments

  • config (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Optional configuration dictionary

Raises:

SystemExit – If required arguments are missing or if API calls fail

Return type:

None

Shift Overrides

Override management for PagerDuty on-call schedules.

This module provides functionality to override existing on-call shifts in PagerDuty, allowing users to: - Override consecutive shifts for a target user - Assign overrides to a specific user - Preview changes with dry-run mode

myshift.override.get_consecutive_target_shifts(session, schedule_id, target_user_id, start_date)[source]

Get consecutive shifts for a target user starting from a specific date.

This function looks for consecutive shifts up to 30 days in the future. It stops when it finds a day without a shift or when it reaches the maximum days.

Parameters:

  • session (Any) – PagerDuty API session

  • schedule_id (str) – Schedule ID to check

  • target_user_id (str) – User ID whose shifts to get

  • start_date (datetime) – Date to start looking for shifts

Returns:

  • start: ISO format start time

  • end: ISO format end time

Return type:

List of dictionaries containing shift information

myshift.override.override_main(args=None, config=None)[source]

Main entry point for the override command.

This function handles the override sub-command, allowing users to: 1. Override consecutive shifts for a target user 2. Assign those shifts to another user 3. Preview changes with dry-run mode

Command-line arguments:

schedule_id: Optional PagerDuty schedule ID to override –start-date: Required start date (YYYY-MM-DD) –end-date: Optional end date (YYYY-MM-DD, inclusive) –user-id: Optional user ID to assign (overrides my_user from config) –user-email: Optional user email to assign (overrides my_user from config) –target-user-id: Optional target user ID whose shifts will be overridden –target-user-email: Optional target user email whose shifts will be overridden –dry-run: Optional flag to preview changes without making them

Parameters:

  • args (Optional[List[str]]) – Optional command line arguments

  • config (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) – Optional configuration dictionary

Raises:

SystemExit – If required arguments are missing or if API calls fail

Return type:

None

Interactive REPL

Interactive REPL (Read-Eval-Print Loop) for myshift commands.

This module provides an interactive command-line interface for myshift, allowing users to execute myshift commands without having to type the ‘myshift’ prefix each time. It supports all main myshift commands and provides help text and command history.

class myshift.repl.MyShiftREPL(config)[source]

Bases: Cmd

Interactive REPL for myshift commands.

This class provides a command-line interface that supports: - Command history (up/down arrows) - Tab completion - Help text for all commands - Graceful exit handling

All myshift commands are available as sub-commands, with the same arguments as their CLI counterparts.

intro = "Welcome to the myshift REPL. Type 'help' or '?' to list commands.\nType 'help <command>' for detailed help on a specific command.\nType 'exit', 'quit', or press Ctrl+D to exit."

Type:    str

prompt = '(myshift) '

Type:    str

__init__(config)[source]

Initialize the REPL with configuration.

Parameters:

config (Dict[str, Any]) – Configuration dictionary for myshift

do_override(arg)[source]

Override PagerDuty schedule rotations.

Usage: override [schedule_id] [options]

Options:
--start-date YYYY-MM-DD

Start date for override

--end-date YYYY-MM-DD

End date for override

--user-id ID

User ID to assign

--user-email EMAIL

User email to assign

--target-user-id ID

Target user ID to override

--target-user-email EMAIL

Target user email to override

--dry-run

Show what would be overridden

Return type:

None

do_upcoming(arg)[source]

Show upcoming on-call shifts for a user.

Usage: upcoming [schedule_id] [options]

Options:
--user-id ID

User ID to check

–user-email EMAIL User email to check –weeks N Number of weeks to look ahead (default: 4)

Return type:

None

do_plan(arg)[source]

Show all on-call shifts for the coming N weeks.

Usage: plan [schedule_id] [options]

Options:
--weeks N

Number of weeks to look ahead (default: 4)

Return type:

None

do_next(arg)[source]

Show the next on-call shift.

Usage: next [schedule_id] [options]

Options:
--user-id ID

User ID to check

–user-email EMAIL User email to check

Return type:

None

Validate or print sample configuration.

Usage: config [options]

Options:
--print

Print sample configuration

Return type:

None

Exit the REPL.

Return type:

bool

Return type:

bool

True to exit the REPL

Handle Ctrl+D (EOF) gracefully.

bool

True to exit the REPL

Main Entry Point

Main entry point for the myshift command-line tool.

This module provides the command-line interface for myshift, handling: - Command-line argument parsing - Sub-command routing - Help text generation

Available sub-commands: - override: Override PagerDuty schedule rotations - upcoming: Show upcoming on-call shifts - plan: Show all on-call shifts - next: Show next on-call shift - repl: Start interactive REPL

myshift.__main__.main()[source]

Main entry point for the myshift CLI tool.

This function: 1. Parses command-line arguments 2. Routes to appropriate sub-command handler 3. Handles help text generation

Sub-commands:

override: Override PagerDuty schedule rotations upcoming: Show upcoming on-call shifts for a user plan: Show all on-call shifts for the coming N weeks next: Show the next on-call shift for a user repl: Start an interactive REPL for myshift commands

Raises:

SystemExit – If invalid command is provided

Return type:

None

Utilities

Utility functions for interacting with the PagerDuty API and managing on-call schedules.

This module provides core functionality for: - PagerDuty API authentication and session management - Schedule ID resolution from command line args or config - User identification and information retrieval - Shift retrieval and management - User mapping and data organization

All datetime operations handle timezone conversion between UTC and local time.

myshift.util.get_pd_session(config)[source]

Create an authenticated PagerDuty API session.

Parameters:

config (Dict[str, Any]) – Configuration dictionary containing pagerduty_token

Return type:

RestApiV2Client

Returns:

Authenticated PagerDuty API client

Raises:

SystemExit – If pagerduty_token is missing from config

myshift.util.resolve_schedule_id(parsed_args, config)[source]

Resolve schedule ID from command line arguments or configuration.

Parameters:

  • parsed_args (Any) – Command line arguments object

  • config (Dict[str, Any]) – Configuration dictionary

Return type:

str

Returns:

Schedule ID string

Raises:

SystemExit – If schedule_id is not found in either source

myshift.util.get_user_id_by_email(session, email)[source]

Get PagerDuty user ID from email address.

Parameters:

  • session (RestApiV2Client) – PagerDuty API session

  • email (str) – User’s email address

Return type:

str

Returns:

User ID string

Raises:

SystemExit – If user is not found

myshift.util.get_user_name_by_id(session, user_id)[source]

Get PagerDuty user’s full name from their ID.

Parameters:

  • session (RestApiV2Client) – PagerDuty API session

  • user_id (str) – User’s PagerDuty ID

Return type:

str

Returns:

User’s full name

Raises:

SystemExit – If user is not found

myshift.util.get_unique_shifts(session, user_id, schedule_id, until)[source]

Get unique on-call shifts for a user in a schedule.

Parameters:

  • session (RestApiV2Client) – PagerDuty API session

  • user_id (str) – PagerDuty user ID

  • schedule_id (str) – PagerDuty schedule ID

  • until (datetime) – End datetime for the search range

Return type:

List[Tuple[datetime, datetime]]

Returns:

List of tuples containing (start_time, end_time) in local timezone. Times are sorted chronologically.

myshift.util.get_all_unique_shifts(session, schedule_id, until, target_tz=None)[source]

Get all unique on-call shifts in a schedule with user information.

Parameters:

  • session (RestApiV2Client) – PagerDuty API session

  • schedule_id (str) – PagerDuty schedule ID

  • until (datetime) – End datetime for the search range

  • target_tz (Optional[~.]) – Target timezone for the output times (defaults to local timezone)

Return type:

List[Tuple[datetime, datetime, str]]

Returns:

List of tuples containing (start_time, end_time, user_id) in target timezone. Times are sorted chronologically.

myshift.util.build_user_map(session, schedule_entries)[source]

Build a map of user objects from schedule entries.

This function builds a map of all user objects referenced in the given schedule entries by collecting unique user IDs and then fetching the full user objects in a single request.

Parameters:

  • session (RestApiV2Client) – PagerDuty API session

  • schedule_entries (List[Tuple[datetime, datetime, str]]) – List of tuples containing (start_time, end_time, user_id)

Return type:

Dict[str, Dict]

Returns:

Dictionary mapping user IDs to their full user objects. Each user object contains all PagerDuty user information.

Configuration

Configuration management for the myshift tool.

This module handles: - Configuration file discovery and loading - Configuration validation - Sample configuration generation

The configuration can be stored in multiple locations: - Linux: $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/myshift.yaml or ~/.config/myshift.yaml - macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/myshift.yaml

myshift.config.get_config_paths()[source]

Get the list of possible configuration file paths in order of precedence.

The paths are checked in the following order: 1. $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/myshift.yaml (Linux) 2. ~/.config/myshift.yaml (Linux) 3. ~/Library/Application Support/myshift.yaml (macOS)

Return type:

List[Path]

Returns:

List of Path objects representing possible config file locations

myshift.config.load_config()[source]

Load configuration from the first available config file.

The configuration file should be a YAML file containing: - pagerduty_token: Required API token for PagerDuty - my_user: Optional user ID or email for the current user - schedule_id: Optional default schedule ID

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Returns:

Configuration dictionary

Raises:

SystemExit – If no config file is found or if there’s an error loading the file

myshift.config.print_sample_config()[source]

Print a sample configuration file.

Return type:

None

myshift.config.validate_config(config)[source]

Validate the configuration parameters.

Checks for: - Presence of required pagerduty_token - Valid format of my_user (if present) - Valid format of schedule_id (if present)

Parameters:

config (Dict[str, Any]) – Configuration dictionary to validate

Raises:

SystemExit – If any validation fails

Return type:

None

myshift.config.config_main(args=None)[source]

Handle the config sub-command.

Return type:

None
